10 Stunning Lakes of Rajasthan for an Adorable Vacation

India > Rajasthan

Explore in Rajasthan

Table of Content

When one thinks about Rajasthan, the terms regal, ethereal, and dry spring to mind. Tales of India's illustrious history are told in the realm of the Maharajas. Nearly everything a traveller may want to see in a perfect vacation location is there in Rajasthan. In Rajasthan, there are several lovely lakes that former Kings constructed to solve the water crisis. See the list of stunning lakes in Rajasthan, and don't forget to cross them off your travel wish list.

About:

Rajasthan, the state where modernity and history coexist, welcomes visitors from all over the world with open arms. In this vibrant Indian state, there are palaces, gardens, museums, and forts, but Rajasthan's lakes are unrivalled in beauty. The Aravalli Hills, surrounding mountains of brilliant white salt, and ruins of great palaces all to the beauty of the lakes. Visit some of Rajasthan's most gorgeous lakes on your next trip here to add a touch of glitz.

01. The Fateh Sagar Lake

The Fateh Sagar Lake, which was built in the 1680s, is undoubtedly one of Rajasthan's most well-known lakes. The lake has three islands, two of which are home to the Udaipur Solar Observatory and Nehru Park, a well-liked picnic area with a famous fountain.

Three islands make up the lake, including the Udaipur Solar Observatory and Nehru Park, a well-liked picnic area with a famous fountain. This azure-coloured gem, encircled by lush hillocks, is what gives Udaipur its nickname of "The Second Kashmir." Take a boat ride at dusk and discover your own personal paradise as the waves play and the sky changes hue.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Sunrise and Sunset
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 1-2 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: Boar Ride at Fateh Nagar Lake
  • Other Places to visit: Balsamand Lake, Jaisamand Lake

02. Lake Pichola

Due to the location of two spectacular palaces that tower over it, Lake Pichola is unquestionably regarded as one of Rajasthan's most recognizable lakes. This gorgeous lake, which looks out over the beautiful City Palace, is framed by the stunning Aravali Hills. On Lake Pichola, there are a total of four islands, and Jag Niwas and Jag Mandir are two of those stunning lake palaces. Visitors can travel to these Palaces via boats and ferries.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Temples and Islands
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 1-2 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: City Palace Museum
  • Other Places to visit: The Fateh Sagar Lake, Ana Sagar Lake

03. Pushkar Lake

Pushkar Lake, which is found in the holy city of Pushkar, is revered in Hindu texts. Hindu mythology holds that the lake was created when one of the lotus petals that Lord Bramha was holding fell to the ground. This lake in Rajasthan features 52 bathing ghats and is bordered by more than 300 temples. One who bathes at Pushkar Lake is said to find salvation and be cured of all skin-related disorders because the water is thought to have healing capabilities.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Sacred Pilgrimages
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 2-3 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: Sacred Temples
  • Other Places to visit: Lake Pichola, The Fateh Sagar Lake

04. Balsamand Lake

The Balsamand Lake in Rajasthan, which is five kilometres from Jodhpur, is the pinnacle of luxury and leisure. Balsamand Lake serves as the backdrop for the regal Balsamand Palace, which has been transformed into an opulent hotel. The palace is surrounded by lush gardens with mango, papaya, guava, plum, and pomegranate trees. At the lake, peacocks can be seen in vast numbers, and animals like jackals casually prowl the area. It is the ideal location for a restorative getaway.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Architecture
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 2-3 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: None
  • Other Places to visit: Jaisamand Lake, Gadisar Lake

05. Jaisamand Lake

Jaisamand Lake, often referred to as Dhebar Lake, is the second-largest man-made lake in Asia. It was constructed in the 17th century by Rana Jai Singh and covers a 50 sq km area. The lake has three islands, and the Jaisamand Wildlife Sanctuary and the summer residences of the Udaipur kings surround it. The magnificent marble dam, which consists of six cenotaphs and a temple to Lord Shiva in the middle, is this location's main draw.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Egypt Archiecture, Boating
  • Best Time to Visit: June to October
  • Duration: 2-3 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: Boating in Jaiamand Lake
  • Other Places to visit: Lake Pichola, Nakki Lake

06. Gadisar Lake

The stunning Gadisar Lake is located outside of Jaisalmer in the dry state of Rajasthan. It resembles an oasis in the middle of a desert. There were no irrigation systems, canals, or other modern means of bringing water to Rajasthan's desert regions back in the middle times. Raja Rawal Jaisal constructed this reservoir while considering the requirements of his subjects. The lake, which lies beside Jaisalmer's fort, offers a simple diversion from the scorching, dry desert climate. Especially when the eastern sky is blood red and the sun rises, casting its rays on the upper floors of Jaisalmer Fort, Gadisar Lake gives stunning views of the lake and the nearby fort.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Architecture
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 1-2 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: None  
  • Other Places to visit: Doodh Talai Lake, Pushkar Lake

07. Ana Sagar Lake

The spectacular artificial lake known as Ana Sagar Lake is situated in the Indian state of Rajasthan's capital city of Ajmer. The greatest time to visit this lake is at sunset when the scenery is most breathtaking. The neighbouring temple offers a particularly beautiful view of the lake. Don't forget to bring your camera so you may record these wonderful and heavenly views. The lake could, however, dry up in the summer. The distance between the lake and Ajmer's main city is about 13 kilometres. In the middle of the lake, there lies an island. Here, visitors adore taking pleasure in boating and water scooter trips.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Sunset and Nature
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 2-3 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: Boating Ana Sagar Lake 
  • Other Places to visit: Sambhar Salt Lake, Jaisamand Lake

08. Nakki Lake

Nakki Lake, also known as the Nakki Jheel locally, is a haven for nature enthusiasts and is located in the Aravalli mountains in Mount Abu. This lake is a wonderful treasure of Mount Abu, surrounded by incredible natural wonders. With a depth of roughly 11,000 meters and a width of a quarter of a mile, it is the first artificial lake in India. The intriguing lake, which sits in the centre of the hill station, is encircled by mountains, rich vegetation, and oddly shaped rocks. It is fascinating to watch Mount Abu's life unfold as you cruise across the calm waters of Nakki Lake. For those who enjoy the outdoors and photography, it is the ideal location.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Vegetation, Nature
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 2-3 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: Mount Abu Trecking
  • Other Places to visit: Gadisar Lake, Lake Pichola

09.Doodh Talai Lake

One of the well-known lakes in Rajasthan is Doodh Talai Lake, which is surrounded by small, lovely mountains. It is one of the most stunning sights in Udaipur and is situated close to Lake Pichola. It offers choices for quick food restaurants, camel and horseback riding, and boat cruises. Here, the first musical fountain was created, and the garden known as the Doodh Talai Musical Garden—became well-known. Manikya Garden, which is adjacent, provides a breathtaking view of Doodh Talai Lake and Lake Pichola.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Boat Rides and Treckking 
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime
  • Duration: 2-4 Hours 

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: Doodh Talai Boating
  • Other Places to visit: Jaisamand Lake, Balsamand Lake

10. Sambhar Salt Lake

Sambhar Salt Lake, which is a little distinct from other lakes in Rajasthan, is made out of water that is saltier than seawater. The largest salt-producing facility in India is located here, on India's largest inland salt lake. It is a historical lake that is also mentioned in the Mahabharata. Since Sambhar Salt Lake is one of Rajasthan's lesser-known lakes, tourists that travel there can experience the local ethnicity and culture firsthand. But a lot of people go to the lake to take advantage of the safaris, birdwatching, and other tourist attractions.

Traveller Information:

  • Famous for: Salt Production, Nature
  • Best Time to Visit: Anytime 
  • Duration: 3-4 Hours

Things to do:

  • Adventure Activities: Salt Lake sightseeing
  • Other Places to visit: Gadisar Lake, Nakki Lake

When one thinks about Rajasthan, the words royal, majestic, and deserts immediately come to mind. Tales of India's illustrious history are told in the realm of the Maharajas. Nearly everything a traveller may want to see in a perfect vacation location is there in Rajasthan. Rajasthan has numerous lovely lakes despite being dry land. Some are man-made, and some are natural; they were built by the kings in the past to address the region's water shortage. What are you still holding out for? Consider visiting Rajasthan and its lovely lakes.
